key_points: Tiger Woods had additional follow-up procedures on Friday for injuries from a car accident on Tuesday in Los Angeles.
Procedures were performed at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center; Woods was previously at Harbor-UCLA Medical Center.
Initial surgery involved a rod in his tibia and screws and pins in his foot and ankle.
Woods' Twitter account confirmed the surgeries were successful and expressed gratitude for the support received.
The accident was ruled 'purely accidental' by the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department.
Officers highlighted that wearing a seatbelt and the vehicle's safety features likely saved Woods' life.
Anish Mahajan, chief medical officer of Harbor-UCLA, commented on Woods' transfer to Cedars-Sinai for continuing care.
Experts predict Woods will need additional surgeries and have a prolonged recovery due to the severity of his leg injuries.
Concerns include the risk of infection and the uncertainty of when Woods can return home.
Woods was in Los Angeles for the Genesis Invitational and promotional activities; he has not competed professionally since December.
spokespersons: Dr. Michael Zuri (Specialist in sports injuries)
Dr. David Agus (Professor of Medicine, USC)
